segment.source: title: Open files and folders with a picker
segment.target: title: Open files and folders with a picker

segment.source: description: Access files and folders by letting the user interact with a picker.
segment.target: description: Access files and folders by letting the user interact with a picker.

segment.source: You can use the FileOpenPicker and FileSavePicker classes to gain access to files, and the FolderPicker to gain access to a folder.
segment.target: You can use the FileOpenPicker and FileSavePicker classes to gain access to files, and the FolderPicker to gain access to a folder.

segment.source: Open files and folders with a picker
segment.target: Open files and folders with a picker

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: FileOpenPicker
segment.target: FileOpenPicker

segment.source: FolderPicker
segment.target: FolderPicker

segment.source: StorageFile
segment.target: StorageFile

segment.source: Access files and folders by letting the user interact with a picker.
segment.target: Access files and folders by letting the user interact with a picker.

segment.source: You can use the FileOpenPicker and FileSavePicker classes to gain access to files, and the FolderPicker to gain access to a folder.
segment.target: You can use the FileOpenPicker and FileSavePicker classes to gain access to files, and the FolderPicker to gain access to a folder.

segment.source: Note Also see the File picker sample.
segment.target: Note Also see the File picker sample.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: Understand async programming for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps
segment.target: Understand async programming for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps

segment.source: You can learn how to write asynchronous apps in C# or Visual Basic, see Call asynchronous APIs in C# or Visual Basic.
segment.target: You can learn how to write asynchronous apps in C# or Visual Basic, see Call asynchronous APIs in C# or Visual Basic.

segment.source: To learn how to write asynchronous apps in C++, see Asynchronous programming in C++.
segment.target: To learn how to write asynchronous apps in C++, see Asynchronous programming in C++.

segment.source: Access permissions to the location
segment.target: Access permissions to the location

segment.source: See File access permissions.
segment.target: See File access permissions.

segment.source: File picker UI
segment.target: File picker UI

segment.source: A file picker displays information to orient users and to provide a consistent experience when users open or save files.
segment.target: A file picker displays information to orient users and to provide a consistent experience when users open or save files.

segment.source: That information includes:
segment.target: That information includes:

segment.source: The current location
segment.target: The current location

segment.source: The item or items that the user picked
segment.target: The item or items that the user picked

segment.source: A tree of locations that the user can browse to.
segment.target: A tree of locations that the user can browse to.

segment.source: These locations include file system locations—such as the Music or Downloads folder—as well as apps that implement the file picker contract (such as Camera, Photos, and Microsoft OneDrive).
segment.target: These locations include file system locations—such as the Music or Downloads folder—as well as apps that implement the file picker contract (such as Camera, Photos, and Microsoft OneDrive).

segment.source: An email app might display a file picker so that the user can pick attachments.
segment.target: An email app might display a file picker so that the user can pick attachments.

segment.source: a file picker with two files picked to be opened.
segment.target: a file picker with two files picked to be opened.

segment.source: How pickers work
segment.target: How pickers work

segment.source: Through a picker, your app can gain access to files and folders on the user's system.
segment.target: Through a picker, your app can gain access to files and folders on the user's system.

segment.source: Through the picker, the user browses their system to pick files (or folders) to open or save to.
segment.target: Through the picker, the user browses their system to pick files (or folders) to open or save to.

segment.source: Your app receives those picks as StorageFile and StorageFolder objects, which you can then operate on.
segment.target: Your app receives those picks as StorageFile and StorageFolder objects, which you can then operate on.

segment.source: The picker uses a single, unified interface to let the user pick files and folders from the files system or from other apps.
segment.target: The picker uses a single, unified interface to let the user pick files and folders from the files system or from other apps.

segment.source: Files picked from other apps are like files from the file system: they are returned as StorageFile objects.
segment.target: Files picked from other apps are like files from the file system: they are returned as StorageFile objects.

segment.source: In general, your app can operate on them in the same ways as other such objects.
segment.target: In general, your app can operate on them in the same ways as other such objects.

segment.source: Other apps make files available by participating in file picker contracts.
segment.target: Other apps make files available by participating in file picker contracts.

segment.source: If you want your app to provide files, a save location, or file updates to other apps, see Integrating with file picker contracts.
segment.target: If you want your app to provide files, a save location, or file updates to other apps, see Integrating with file picker contracts.

segment.source: For example, you might call the file picker in your app so that your user can open a file.
segment.target: For example, you might call the file picker in your app so that your user can open a file.

segment.source: This makes your app the calling app.
segment.target: This makes your app the calling app.

segment.source: The file picker interacts with the system and/or other apps to let the user navigate and pick the file.
segment.target: The file picker interacts with the system and/or other apps to let the user navigate and pick the file.

segment.source: When your user chooses a file, the file picker returns that file to your app.
segment.target: When your user chooses a file, the file picker returns that file to your app.

segment.source: Here's the process for the case where the user chooses a file from another app, such as OneDrive.
segment.target: Here's the process for the case where the user chooses a file from another app, such as OneDrive.

segment.source: In this case OneDrive is the providing app.
segment.target: In this case OneDrive is the providing app.

segment.source: a daigram that shows the process of one app getting a file to open from another app using the file picker as an interface bewteen the two apps.
segment.target: a daigram that shows the process of one app getting a file to open from another app using the file picker as an interface bewteen the two apps.

segment.source: Pick a single file to open it: complete code listing
segment.target: Pick a single file to open it: complete code listing

segment.source: For code to pick multiple files, see the File picker sample.
segment.target: For code to pick multiple files, see the File picker sample.

segment.source: Pick a single file to open it: step-by-step
segment.target: Pick a single file to open it: step-by-step

segment.source: Using a file picker involves creating and customizing a file picker object, and then showing the file picker so the user can pick one or more items.
segment.target: Using a file picker involves creating and customizing a file picker object, and then showing the file picker so the user can pick one or more items.

segment.source: Create and customize a FileOpenPicker
segment.target: Create and customize a FileOpenPicker

segment.source: Set properties on the file picker object that are relevant to your users and your app.
segment.target: Set properties on the file picker object that are relevant to your users and your app.

segment.source: For guidelines to help you decide how to customize the file picker, see Guidelines and checklist for file pickers.
segment.target: For guidelines to help you decide how to customize the file picker, see Guidelines and checklist for file pickers.

segment.source: This example creates a rich, visual display of pictures in a convenient location that the user can pick from by setting three properties: ViewMode, SuggestedStartLocation, and FileTypeFilter.
segment.target: This example creates a rich, visual display of pictures in a convenient location that the user can pick from by setting three properties: ViewMode, SuggestedStartLocation, and FileTypeFilter.

segment.source: Setting ViewMode to the Thumbnail PickerViewMode enum value creates a rich, visual display by using picture thumbnails to represent files in the file picker.
segment.target: Setting ViewMode to the Thumbnail PickerViewMode enum value creates a rich, visual display by using picture thumbnails to represent files in the file picker.

segment.source: Do this for picking visual files such as pictures or videos.
segment.target: Do this for picking visual files such as pictures or videos.

segment.source: Otherwise, use PickerViewMode.List.
segment.target: Otherwise, use PickerViewMode.List.

segment.source: A hypothetical email app with Attach Picture or Video and Attach Document features would set the ViewMode appropriate to the feature before showing the file picker.
segment.target: A hypothetical email app with Attach Picture or Video and Attach Document features would set the ViewMode appropriate to the feature before showing the file picker.

segment.source: Setting SuggestedStartLocation to Pictures using PickerLocationId.PicturesLibrary starts the user in a location where they're likely to find pictures.
segment.target: Setting SuggestedStartLocation to Pictures using PickerLocationId.PicturesLibrary starts the user in a location where they're likely to find pictures.

segment.source: Set SuggestedStartLocation to a location appropriate for the type of file being picked, for example Music, Pictures, Videos, or Documents.
segment.target: Set SuggestedStartLocation to a location appropriate for the type of file being picked, for example Music, Pictures, Videos, or Documents.

segment.source: From the start location, the user can navigate to other locations.
segment.target: From the start location, the user can navigate to other locations.

segment.source: Using FileTypeFilter to specify file types keeps the user focused on picking files that are relevant.
segment.target: Using FileTypeFilter to specify file types keeps the user focused on picking files that are relevant.

segment.source: To replace previous file types in the FileTypeFilter with new entries, use ReplaceAll instead of Add.
segment.target: To replace previous file types in the FileTypeFilter with new entries, use ReplaceAll instead of Add.

segment.source: Show the FileOpenPicker
segment.target: Show the FileOpenPicker

segment.source: To pick a single file
segment.target: To pick a single file

segment.source: Pick a folder: complete code listing
segment.target: Pick a folder: complete code listing

segment.source: Tip Whenever your app accesses a file or folder through a picker, add it to your app's FutureAccessList or MostRecentlyUsedList to keep track of it.
segment.target: Tip Whenever your app accesses a file or folder through a picker, add it to your app's FutureAccessList or MostRecentlyUsedList to keep track of it.

segment.source: You can learn more about using these lists in How to track recently-used files and folders.
segment.target: You can learn more about using these lists in How to track recently-used files and folders.
